fields.summary: CC cleanrestart changes default policy of iptable INPUT chain to ACCEPT with regards to iptables-preload file information

fields.description:
It appears that /usr/share/eucalyptus/euca_ipt is incorrectly setting up rules
for IPTables. /var/log/eucalyptus/http-cc_error_log shows the errors below on
every IPTables operation that occurs when running and terminating instances
(could be more but these are what I checked while troubleshooting another
issue).

  
It looks as though the last line of the iptables-restore file is trying to do
a listing of a specific chain with numeric output when that isn't an operation
supported by iptables-restore.

  
The second issue below attempts to delete a rule that is no longer present in
IPTables so it fails.

  
IPTables still works even though this is occuring but it is still an error
that could confuse an user if they are having other possible issues with
IPTables. We should try to limit the number of errors that we consistently
print to logs at the very least to help out support.

  
=======================================================================

  

DO OLD EUCA_IPT

iptables-restore: line 8 failed

iptables-restore failed: rulefile contents:

# Generated by iptables-save v1.3.5 on Wed Mar 14 23:58:30 2012

*filter

:INPUT ACCEPT [665:294955]

:FORWARD DROP [0:0]

:OUTPUT ACCEPT [665:295339]

-A FORWARD -m conntrack --ctstate ESTABLISHED -j ACCEPT

-A FORWARD -d ! 10.110.190.0/255.255.254.0 -j ACCEPT

-L qMvv0p1gX6w2MMey9f8nDg== -n

COMMIT

# Completed on Wed Mar 14 23:58:30 2012

[EUCAERROR] iptables-restore failed

DO OLD EUCA_IPT

done

DO OLD EUCA_IPT

iptables-restore: line 9 failed

iptables-restore failed: rulefile contents:

# Generated by iptables-save v1.3.5 on Wed Mar 14 23:58:30 2012

*filter

:INPUT ACCEPT [0:0]

:FORWARD DROP [0:0]

:OUTPUT ACCEPT [0:0]

:qMvv0p1gX6w2MMey9f8nDg== - [0:0]

-A FORWARD -m conntrack --ctstate ESTABLISHED -j ACCEPT

-A FORWARD -d ! 10.110.190.0/255.255.254.0 -j ACCEPT

-D FORWARD -j qMvv0p1gX6w2MMey9f8nDg==

COMMIT

# Completed on Wed Mar 14 23:58:30 2012

[EUCAERROR] iptables-restore failed

  
======================================================================

--   
______________________________________

Andrew Hamilton - Systems Administrator

Eucalyptus Systems

www.eucalyptus.com

Support Hotline: +1 805 845-8400

Support Website: https://support.eucalyptus.com

______________________________________
fields.summary: euca_ipt attempts iptables-restore commands that fail.

comments.body:
Originally posted on 2012-03-15 04:16:18 by ahamilton

Wed Mar 14 21:16:18 2012: Request 6613 was acted upon.
 Transaction: Ticket created by andrew.hamilton
       Queue: Engineering-Support
     Subject: euca_ipt attempts iptables-restore commands that fail.
       Owner: Nobody
  Requestors: andrew.hamilton@eucalyptus.com
      Status: new
 Ticket <URL: https://support.eucalyptus.com/Ticket/Display.html?id=6613 >


It appears that /usr/share/eucalyptus/euca_ipt is incorrectly setting up rules
for IPTables. /var/log/eucalyptus/http-cc_error_log shows the errors below on
every IPTables operation that occurs when running and terminating instances
(could be more but these are what I checked while troubleshooting another
issue).

It looks as though the last line of the iptables-restore file is trying to do a
listing of a specific chain with numeric output when that isn't an operation
supported by iptables-restore.

The second issue below attempts to delete a rule that is no longer present in
IPTables so it fails.

IPTables still works even though this is occuring but it is still an error that
could confuse an user if they are having other possible issues with IPTables.
We should try to limit the number of errors that we consistently print to logs
at the very least to help out support.

=======================================================================

DO OLD EUCA_IPT iptables-restore: line 8 failed iptables-restore failed:
rulefile contents: # Generated by iptables-save v1.3.5 on Wed Mar 14 23:58:30
2012 *filter :INPUT ACCEPT [665:294955] :FORWARD DROP [0:0] :OUTPUT ACCEPT
[665:295339] -A FORWARD -m conntrack --ctstate ESTABLISHED -j ACCEPT -A FORWARD
-d ! 10.110.190.0/255.255.254.0 -j ACCEPT -L qMvv0p1gX6w2MMey9f8nDg== -n COMMIT
# Completed on Wed Mar 14 23:58:30 2012 [EUCAERROR] iptables-restore failed DO
OLD EUCA_IPT done DO OLD EUCA_IPT iptables-restore: line 9 failed
iptables-restore failed: rulefile contents: # Generated by iptables-save v1.3.5
on Wed Mar 14 23:58:30 2012 *filter :INPUT ACCEPT [0:0] :FORWARD DROP [0:0]
:OUTPUT ACCEPT [0:0] :qMvv0p1gX6w2MMey9f8nDg== - [0:0] -A FORWARD -m conntrack
--ctstate ESTABLISHED -j ACCEPT -A FORWARD -d ! 10.110.190.0/255.255.254.0 -j
ACCEPT -D FORWARD -j qMvv0p1gX6w2MMey9f8nDg== COMMIT # Completed on Wed Mar 14
23:58:30 2012 [EUCAERROR] iptables-restore failed
====================================================================== --
______________________________________
Andrew Hamilton - Systems Administrator
Eucalyptus Systems
www.eucalyptus.com
Support Hotline: +1 805 845-8400
Support Website: https://support.eucalyptus.com
______________________________________

Originally posted on 2012-03-15 16:30:25 by dstagnaro
Good subject to cover in an internal knowledge article. I'll take that.

Originally posted on 2012-03-15 16:30:25 by admin
https://support.eucalyptus.com/Ticket/Display.html?id=6613 This is a comment.
It is not sent to the Requestor(s): Good subject to cover in an internal
knowledge article. I'll take that.

Originally posted on 2012-03-15 16:34:54 by nurmi
Andrew,

  
Both of these errors are due to 'negative tests' that the CC performs to keep
iptables state correct.  The '-L' is the CC looking for existence of a chain
(i.e. the command fails if the chain isn't present, which is what the CC is
trying to determine).  The '-D' is verifying that the rule has been fully
cleared (i.e. it will fail when the rule is no longer present).

  
It is understood that these types of negative tests are confusing, and we try
to keep the actual eucalyptus logs (cc.log in this case) free from negative
error results (healthy CC will have few or no EUCAERROR lines).  However, the
http_cc_error_log file is out of our control in a sense, in that the messages
printed here are largely from eucalyptus dependencies (iptables, dhcpd, etc).

  
A suggestion here is to inform users that http_cc_error_log is for
support/eng. activities, but it will be very difficult for users to use this
log for debugging (since euca doesn't exclusively control its contents).  Does
this make sense?

  
Core issue understood, we develop with this principle in mind, but largely we
focus on euca logs (cc.log, nc.log).

  
-D

rulefile contents: # Generated by iptables-save v1.3.5 on Wed Mar 14 >

> ACCEPT > [665:295339] -A FORWARD -m conntrack --ctstate ESTABLISHED -j
ACCEPT > -A FORWARD > -d ! 10.110.190.0/255.255.254.0 -j ACCEPT -L
qMvv0p1gX6w2MMey9f8nDg== > -n COMMIT > # Completed on Wed Mar 14 23:58:30 2012
[EUCAERROR] iptables-restore > failed DO > OLD EUCA_IPT done DO OLD EUCA_IPT
iptables-restore: line 9 failed > iptables-restore failed: rulefile contents:
# Generated by iptables- > save v1.3.5 > on Wed Mar 14 23:58:30 2012 *filter
:INPUT ACCEPT [0:0] :FORWARD DROP > [0:0] > :OUTPUT ACCEPT [0:0]
:qMvv0p1gX6w2MMey9f8nDg== - [0:0] -A FORWARD -m > conntrack > --ctstate
ESTABLISHED -j ACCEPT -A FORWARD -d ! > 10.110.190.0/255.255.254.0 -j > ACCEPT
-D FORWARD -j qMvv0p1gX6w2MMey9f8nDg== COMMIT # Completed on > Wed Mar 14 >
23:58:30 2012 [EUCAERROR] iptables-restore failed >

Administrator > Eucalyptus Systems > www.eucalyptus.com > Support Hotline: +1
805 845-8400 > Support Website: https://support.eucalyptus.com >
______________________________________

Originally posted on 2012-03-15 16:34:55 by nurmi

<URL: https://support.eucalyptus.com/Ticket/Display.html?id=6613 >

Andrew,

Both of these errors are due to 'negative tests' that the CC performs to keep
iptables state correct. The '-L' is the CC looking for existence of a chain
(i.e. the command fails if the chain isn't present, which is what the CC is
trying to determine). The '-D' is verifying that the rule has been fully
cleared (i.e. it will fail when the rule is no longer present).

It is understood that these types of negative tests are confusing, and we try
to keep the actual eucalyptus logs (cc.log in this case) free from negative
error results (healthy CC will have few or no EUCAERROR lines). However, the
http_cc_error_log file is out of our control in a sense, in that the messages
printed here are largely from eucalyptus dependencies (iptables, dhcpd, etc).

A suggestion here is to inform users that http_cc_error_log is for support/eng.
activities, but it will be very difficult for users to use this log for
debugging (since euca doesn't exclusively control its contents). Does this make
sense?

Core issue understood, we develop with this principle in mind, but largely we
focus on euca logs (cc.log, nc.log).

-D

moving to documentation to review whether or not clarity around what the logfiles are and what they do (in this context) is in order.

This issue was previously scheduled to be worked on in more than one sprint:
* '3.3 Sprint 4' (on board 'Test 3.3 Board')
* '3.3 Sprint 4' (on board 'Copy of 3.3 Release Board')

Starting from JIRA Agile 6.3, an issue can only belong to a single future sprint. Read more about this change: http://docs.atlassian.com/agile/docs-0640/Sprint+Marker+Migration

This issue is now scheduled for future sprint '3.3 Sprint 4' (on board 'Copy of 3.3 Release Board').

If this is incorrect, please update the issue accordingly.
